document.text: The general election in Appomat tox county Tuesday was like the present war in E u ro p e.... it was All quiet on the front! With no contests, and only one candidate for county offices, -only 613 voters wont to the polls! There were over 1,800 eltg ble Viters. The total vote by precincts was as follows Court Home, 194 Cheatwood, 8 Chap, 22 Rocks, 25 Pamplin, 04 Walkers Church, 35 Clover Hill, 81 Agee, 47 Oakville, 50 Stonewall, 87. The total vote for the unopposed candidates was For state senator, Charles T. Mos es, 686. For home of delegates, John B. Boatwright 569.. For commonweaths attorney, W. M. Abbitt, 580. For county treasurer, R. L. Burke, 572. For commissioner of the revenue, J. H. OBrien, 568. For sheriff, H. W. McKinney 586. For supervisor Clover Hill dis trict, F . A . OBrien 181. For supervisor Southside district. , Don Moses, 214. For supervisor Stonewall district, T.E.Owen, 168.

document.text: The Board of Supervisor of Ap pomattox County, and tha Town Council of the Town of Pamplin. Va., are offering a toward of ONE HUNDRED DOLLARS,. 100.00 for information loading to the nr reat and conviction of the party who hot and killed Mrs. Robert Ranaone Davis, at her homo, on Jnn 18, 1941, near Pamplin, Ap pomattox County, Va. H. W. McKinney, Sheriff of Appomattox County, Va Mrs. Davis was killed instantly when shot in the back by a shot from a gun taken from her o.wn home. Her body was not found un til Thursday morning. She lived alone, about one mile west of the town of Pamplin. Since the shoot ing, co-unty officers have tracked down all information unearthed but have nmde no arrests. The gun was found near _ the house, but yielded no finger-prints.

document.text: Supervisors a n d county of ficials of Appomattox county met at the court house Tues-  day night of this week and agreed to a slashing of the county tax rate and salaries.j The tax-rate will be cut t 1.50 and salaries will be - duced 10 per cent, it fit. agreed. The present i levies run from 1.80 to 1.95. The reduction is expected to cause a bolstering of confidence locally and will be warmly wel comed by tax payers. No con certed demand for a reduction had been made by citizens, but the supervisors and county of f a l s felt that the cut was in .ine with steps already taken by several other counties. The supervisors also felt it best to act in advance of widespread dissatisfaction that might be forthcoming if theratewere not . educed and wisely averted any m a s s meetings of tax payers such as a number of other coun ies have experienced. Th i s act is expected to renew confi dence in the administration of county affairs, and cooperation -vill now be sought in an effort -o avoid drastic cut in upkeep jf roads and the conduct of the jchools. The- statement signed by county supervisors, follows To T h e Taxpayers of Appo mattox Count Realizing the financial con dition of the farmers and citi zens of our county, brought about by the drought of last year, a n d the unprecedented depression whichwe are pass ing, and small demand and low prices for all farm products, and while all of us now receive the lowest salary and compen sation allowed by state laws, but desiring to help relieve the tax burden of o u r people to some extent, hereby express cur willingness and voluntarily agree to accept a ten per cent cut in salary or compensation for the year beginning January 1st, 1932, and pledge ourselves to do everything possible to practice economy in the admin istration of the county affairs, so that the county, school and road levy m a y be reduced to the lowest possible figure. The above ten per cent does not ap ply to the County Treasurer or the Commissioner of the Rev enue, as the reduction in levy automatically reduces their compensation more than ten per cent. C. W. Smith, Clerk R. L. Burke, County Treasurer Jo el W. Flood, Commonwealth Attorney H. W. McKinney, Sheriff J. H. OBrien, Comr. of Revenue J. A. Burke, Supt, of Schools F. A. OBrien, Supervisor Don Moses, Super visor T. E. Owen, Supervisor E. LeRoy Smith, Chairman School Board ,T. J. Ligon, Member School Board j  o! Davidson, Member School Board. ,, 111 viw of the, foregoing, we iu undersififned members of th e Board of Supervisors, whose duty it is to make up the bud get and fix the levy bf the coun ty, desire to state that we wish to do everything we can to low- er the tax rate to t h e lowest possible figure, consistent with sound financing and safeguard ing the institutions of our coun ty. We are sure we can make a substantial reduction in the levy for th e next fiscal year, and agree to make the total levy 1.50 on the 100.00 for all purposes, thus reducing the taxes of the people approxi mately 12,450.00. We real ize this means a substantial cut in county affairs, road building, and length of school term. This includes a reduction in the sal aries and wages of everyone employed by the county, but we feel that an emergency exists , Continued on Page 4

document.text: opening Of the bank after the recent bank holiday. He drew! a gun on the cashier, A. R- Harwóod, and was in the midst of an attempt to force payment of the account when sheriff H W. McKinney a n d J. E. Dir- vviddie entered the bank at the behest of Miss Jessalyn Han cock, stenographer. A scuffle followed in which the gun waf harmlessly fired and Harris ar rested Mr. Harris has been released upon a 2,500 peace bond. Mr. Harwood, in explaining the facts of the case yesterday stated JL want to say to everybody interested that I consider th e pffair in the bank Friday, Nov 17, With Mr. Harris most un fortunate, and I wish from thé bottom of my heart for the sake of all concerned, it had never happened. I do hope that people, wherever interest ed, will not listen to gossip as decisions should all be made based on facts after looking at the case from every angle. The officers have a duty they cant escape, no matter h o w much they might like to do so. I have no ill feelings to ward Mr. Harris or any of his family. I have tried all through the past 5 years of try ing times to act fairly and courteously towards everybody and db not think Mr. Harris would have threatened my life if he had not been temporarily beside himself. We should all be very grate ful that no one was hurt or killed as it could have been much worse. The people of Appomattox county always act sensibly and with gpod judgement in times of strain and I believe they wil again be fair to everybody in this case. - --------- o

document.text: CONCERN Whereas, on April 10th, 1913, a resolution was dopted by he Dem ocratic County Committee of Appo mattox County, providing for a Pri mary Election to nominate Candi da.es for County and District Offi cers of Apjgomattox County,_ an also providing that all can.idar.cs for nomination for County and Dis trict Offices, as well as members of the Legislature of Virginia, should give no.ice of their candidacy, to the Chairman of said County Com mittee, as provided by law, on or before sixty days prior to the date of said primary, and Whcre s, the following persons for the offices set opposite their names, are the only candidates in said county who have filed their notices, according to law, and i n compliance with said resolution, to- wit For Commonwealth Attorney, W. M. Abbitt For County Treasurer, R. L. Burke . For County Clerk, C. W. Smith For Sheriff, H. W. McKinney For Commissioner of the Reve nue, J. H. OBrien For Clover Hill District Officers For Supervisor, F. A. OBrien For Southside District Officers For Supervisor, George Abbitt, Jr. For Justice of the Peace, T W. Moses Now, therefore, I, W. M. Abbitt, Chairman of the Democratic Execu tive Commit.ee of Appomattox Co unty, by virtue of the provision of the Democratic Party Plan, hereby declare aforementioned parties to be the Democratic Nominees for the offices set opposite their respective names, except for State Senate and Member of the House of Delegates, who have been by proper authori ties declared the nominees, to be voted for in the General Election to be held on Tuesday Nov. 2nd, 1943 and as such nominees entit led to the support and votes of all Democrats, the same as if they had been chosen in a primary election, andWhereas, more than one candi date for the office of Supervisor in Stongwall District have filed their notices of candidacy with me, a s provided by said resolution afore said, their names and the offices for which they are candidates res pectively, will be certified by me as provided by Sec. 230 of the pri mary law to the Electoral Board of Appomattox Oouny, to be by it printed on the primary ballot. Given under my hand this 7th day of June, 1943. W. M. Abbitt, Chairman Democratic County Executive Com- mi tee of Appomattox County. 6-10-ltc

McKinney, Sheriff and Admr. of C. F. Harvey, decd., A. M. Wood, J. W, Franklin and S. P. Lov- ing, by O. G. Kendig, his committee late parteners of C. F. Harvey, decd., doing business as Pamplin Smoking Pipe and Mfg. Co., and State Bank of Pamplin, a Corp. Plaintiff and Defendants in the above suit. You are hereby notified that I have fixed the 16th day of May, 1929, at 10 a. m. as the time and my office at Appomattox C. H., as the place for taking the several ac counts in the above styled suit, ordered by the decree therein, of April term, 1929, to-wit First An account showing the as sets and liabilities of the partner ship set fourth in the pleculing in this cause. Second An account of the earn ings and profits of said partnership as of the time of the death of plain tiffs decedent, and as of the time of taking said account, showing what amount, if anything, is due to each of said partners on account thereof and what liens, if any, are binding on the interest of any of said part ners. Third And an account of any other matters which may be deemed pertient to said Commissioner, or that may be required by any party in interest. Given under my hand the date above. C. W. SMITH, Comr. in Chancery. 4-18-4t
